item.title: Modeling 101 for Public Health
item.description:
Event: 2022 Council of State and Territorial Epidemiologists (CTSE)/CDC Infectious Disease Forecasting Workshop in Atlanta, GA.

About: A seminar introducing infectious disease modeling for public health officials, with a particular focus on interpreting model results and assessing model utility.

Materials: Lecture slides and associated R code are available on Github. A modified version of this seminar is also available on the CSTE Learn Platform.

item.title: Intro to Infectious Disease Modeling (in R)
item.description: A seminar introducing infectious disease modeling, with a particular focus on compartmental models and how to code them in R. Lecture slides and code are available on Github.

item.title: Math, Models, and Social Mixing
item.description:
From the RockEDU event page:

“This week on Data for the People, postdocs Chloe Pasin and Sinead Morris will talk about how scientists are applying hypothetical modeling and math to predict what can happen when social distancing rules are lifted at different time points, and using different strategies. More specifically, they will present a case study from The Lancet published on March 25, 2020 that applied a specific model to predict what would happen in Wuhan, China under different scenarios of social mixing (i.e. when and how the population stops social distancing).”

The talk recording is available on the RockEDU Science Outreach youtube channel.

item.title: Disease modeling short course
item.description:
Event: Summer bootcamp for infectious disease modeling

Location: The Institute of Statistical Mathematics, Tokyo

Event URL: https://sites.google.com/site/modelinfection/home/shortcourse4

Lecture: The lecture introduced students to ways in which the SIR model can be applied to real disease outbreaks. I focussed on a past project that developed a statistical SIR framework to model the spatiotemporal dynamics of dolphin morbillivirus. The slides from the talk are below.
